avalancheActivity.comment: As a consequence of the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The avalanches can in isolated cases reach large size. The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise.
avalancheActivity.highlights: The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.

snowpackStructure.comment: The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. 5 to 15 cm of snow will fall. The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow.

avalancheActivity.comment: The fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 2200 m. The avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. These avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. Below approximately 2200 m medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible.
avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.

snowpackStructure.comment: 15 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2500 m. The strong wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

avalancheActivity.comment: The fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 2200 m. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Below approximately 2200 m small to medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible.
avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow and wind slabs at high altitude. Below approximately 2200 m moist and wet avalanches are possible.

snowpackStructure.comment: 20 to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 2500 m. The southwesterly wind will transport the new snow. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The rain will give rise to gradual moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2000 m. In all altitude zones only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

avalancheActivity.comment: As a consequence of a strong wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the last few days at elevated altitudes. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2200 m. The more recent wind slabs are to be bypassed in very steep terrain. As a consequence of the rain, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase a little in all regions at low and intermediate altitudes.
avalancheActivity.highlights: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines.

snowpackStructure.comment:
The snowpack is largely stable and has a loosely bonded surface. This applies in particular in shady places that are protected from the wind. In isolated cases new snow is lying on a hard crust.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year. The rain will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
